qas.question: How many Japanese forces were in Korea in 1945?
Where were 723,000 Koreans sent to work?

answers.text: overseas empire and in metropolitan Japan

qas.question: Who did Japan collaborate with to help control the citizens of Korea?
By 1945, what percentage of Koreans made up the Japanese labor force?
What army were Korean men conscripted into?

context: During World War II, Japan used Korea's food, livestock, and metals for their war effort. Japanese forces in Korea increased from 46,000 soldiers in 1941 to <a0_0>300,000<a0_0/> in 1945. Japanese Korea conscripted 2.6 million forced laborers controlled with a collaborationist <a2_0>Korean police force<a2_0/>; some 723,000 people were sent to work in the <a1_0>overseas empire and in metropolitan Japan<a1_0/>. By 1942, Korean men were being conscripted into the <a4_0>Imperial Japanese Army<a4_0/>. By January 1945, Koreans made up <a3_0>32%<a3_0/> of Japan's labor force. At the end of the war, other world powers did not recognize Japanese rule in Korea and Taiwan.
